awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Computational Correlations: A New Tool for Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the computational hardness of securely realizing cryptographic primitives is a fundamental problem in cryptography. One such vital cryptographic primitive is oblivious transfer and understanding the essence of implementing it has significant consequences to cryptography, like bringing secure multi-party computation closer to reality. This research develops a new theory to explore this broad concept, namely the theory of computational correlations. This project defines an appropriate notion of computational correlations, leverages security guarantees to argue computational hardness results, and introduces the concept of computational channels in design and analysis of practical obvious transfer protocols.  

The theory of computational correlations is, among various other applications, useful to exhibit necessity of oblivious transfer to achieve certain notions of security and design rate optimal oblivious transfer protocols in the computational setting. Training the next generation of cryptography research and security professionals is a central goal of this project. This includes the design and development of new courses and course materials for undergraduate and graduate courses, development of active learning materials for the dissemination of knowledge, and engagement of minority and women students in research.

por.por_cntn:
Secure computation allows mutually distrusting parties to compute securely over their private data. The objective of secure computation is to allow the participants of computation to obtain their intended outcome without divulging any additional information. The task of secure computation is increasingly becoming challenging in the presence of more sophisticated adversarial models. For example, an adversarial party may refuse to participate in the protocol any further. Alternatively, the adversary may obtain information about the private state of the parties. In the presence of such strong adversaries, it is challenging to ascertain the security that one can achieve in secure computation protocols. Once the feasibility limits are determined, the objective becomes to implement secure computation most efficiently. 


1) Efficiency in Computation. The contributions of this project proceeds along two primary lines (A) Efficiency of general secure computation, and (B) Efficiency of secure computation of fundamental primitives in the presence of strong adversaries.

-- Part A. Several fast general secure computation protocols over arithmetic circuits proceed by utilizing the unpredictable nature of noisy random codes. However, any boolean circuit could not benefit from these efficiency improvements. We introduce a novel embedding technique that allows for the secure computation of several boolean gates in parallel from one large field multiplication. Thus, transferring all efficiency improvements for arithmetic circuits to boolean circuits. 

-- Part B. Coin-tossing is one of the most fundamental primitives in secure computation. Understanding the limits of security achievable by coin-tossing, in turn, enables the study of more complicated functionalities. This work studies coin-tossing protocol under various adversarial models. The essential technical contribution is an inductive potential-based security argument. This technique is primarily employed to understand the security achievable by a coin-tossing protocol in the presence of adversaries who may refuse to participate in the protocol any further. 


2) Measuring Leakage-resilience. Our research indicates that all resources are not equally reliable for secure computation when an adversary may find additional information on the private state of the parties participating in the secure protocol. The project identifies a new technique to measure the leakage-resilience of resources that enable secure computation numerically. Furthermore, the research lays the foundations for developing a quantitative measurement of leakage-resilience. 


The research contributes to fundamental topics in mathematics, like, algebraic geometry, martingales, information theory. Several of these results are fundamental to simplifying existing proof techniques. A new course, ``Mathematical toolkit in CS'' developed by the PI, includes these simplifications and new results. This course provides incoming graduate students and exceptional undergraduate students in CS (and related departments) a crash course on fundamental topics in mathematics and theoretical computer science. The research conducted in this project was presented at top research venues. This project also enabled the training of multiple graduate students in advanced mathematics, information theory, and secure computation. Furthermore, the research conducted in this proposal shall enable designing secure computation protocol with higher efficiency, which may bring secure computation closer to deployment in broader applications in the real world.
